snippet: A federal judge ruled that the city, which was sued after Tropical Storm Irene, has failed to accommodate for the needs of disabled residents during times of crisis.
abstract: Federal Judge Jesse M Furman rules that New York City violated rights of about 900,000 of its residents with disabilities under Americans WIth Disabilities Act by failing to have plans in place for their needs during emergencies; ruling arose from class-action lawsuit filed in 2011 after Tropical Storm Irene, but came into sharper focus after Hurricane Sandy, when many New Yorkers with disabilities were stranded for days in high-rise buildings.

byline.original: By MARC SANTORA and BENJAMIN WEISER

lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled that the city, which was sued after Tropical Storm Irene, has failed to accommodate for the needs of disabled residents during times of crisis.

headline.main: Court Says New York Neglected Disabled in Emergencies
headline.print_headline: U.S. Judge Says City Neglected Disabled
